answer_html: There exists a continuous function \(f\) on the interval [a,b ], with a < b such that there exists a real number y between \(f\)(a) and \(f\)(b) such that for all real number c in the interval [a, b ] we have \(f\)(c) \(\neq\) y”.
hints_html:
A theorem is always a statement of the type A \(\Rightarrow\) B and since we have the equivalence

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle A \Rightarrow B \equiv \lnot A \lor B\end{aligned}\]

we can deduce that the negation of such a statement is

\[\begin{aligned} \lnot(A \Rightarrow B) &\equiv \lnot(\lnot A \lor B)\\ &\equiv A \land \lnot B\end{aligned}\]

Or in plain English: the negation of A implies B is when A is true and B isn’t.

The previous hints claims that a theorem is of the type A \(\Rightarrow\) B. Can you identify each of A and B?
hints_latex:
A theorem is always a statement of the type \emph{A} $\Rightarrow$
\emph{B} and since we have the equivalence

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
A \Rightarrow B \equiv \lnot A \lor B
\end{align*} we can deduce that the negation
of such a statement is

\begin{align*}
\lnot(A \Rightarrow B) &\equiv \lnot(\lnot A \lor B)\\
&\equiv A \land \lnot B
\end{align*} Or in plain English: the negation of \emph{A} implies
\emph{B} is when \emph{A} is true and \emph{B} isn't.

The previous hints claims that a theorem is of the type \emph{A}
$\Rightarrow$ \emph{B}. Can you identify each of \emph{A} and \emph{B}?
hints_raw:
A theorem is always a statement of the type ''A'' <math>\Rightarrow</math> ''B'' and since we have the equivalence
:<math>\displaystyle
A \Rightarrow B \equiv \lnot A \lor B
</math>
we can deduce that the negation of such a statement is
:<math>\displaystyle
\begin{align}
\lnot(A \Rightarrow B) &\equiv \lnot(\lnot A \lor B)\\
&\equiv A \land \lnot B
\end{align}
</math>
Or in plain English: the negation of ''A'' implies ''B'' is when ''A'' is true and ''B'' isn't.
The previous hints claims that a theorem is of the type ''A'' <math>\Rightarrow</math> ''B''. Can you identify each of ''A'' and ''B''?
sols_html:
The Intermediate Value Theorem states:

For any real numbers a < b, and for any function

\(f: [a,b]\to \mathbb{R},\)

if f is continuous on the interval [a,b ], then for every real number y between f(a) and f(b), there exists a real number c in the interval [a,b ] such that f(c)=y.

We can usually spot implications in theorems by the use of the word then. So here we have that the statement A is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle A\end{aligned}\]

= \(f\) is a continuous function on the interval [a,b ], with a < b. and the conclusion of the theorem is statement B

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle B\end{aligned}\]

= for all real numbers y between \(f\)(a) and \(f\)(b) there exists a real number c in the interval [a, b ] such that \(f\)(c) = y.

And so the Intermediate Value Theorem is simply the statement

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle A \Rightarrow B\end{aligned}\]

And its negation is the statement

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle A \land \lnot B\end{aligned}\]

We’ll need the negation of statement B for this:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \lnot B\end{aligned}\]

= there exists a real number y between \(f\)(a) and \(f\)(b) such that for all real number c in the interval [a, b ] we have \(f\)(c) \(\neq\) y.

And so the negation is

There exists a continuous function \(f\) on the interval [a,b ], with a < b such that there exists a real number y between \(f\)(a) and \(f\)(b) such that for all real number c in the interval [a, b ] we have \(f\)(c) \(\neq\) y”.
sols_latex:
The Intermediate Value Theorem states:

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
For any real numbers \emph{a} \textless{} \emph{b}, and for any function

$f: [a,b]\to \mathbb{R},$

if \emph{f} is continuous on the interval {[}\emph{a},\emph{b} {]}, then
for every real number \emph{y} between \emph{f}(\emph{a}) and
\emph{f}(\emph{b}), there exists a real number \emph{c} in the interval
{[}\emph{a},\emph{b} {]} such that \emph{f}(\emph{c})=\emph{y}.
\end{description}

We can usually spot implications in theorems by the use of the word
\emph{then}. So here we have that the statement \emph{A} is

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle A
\end{align*} = \emph{$f$ is a continuous function on the interval}
{[}\emph{a},\emph{b} {]}, \emph{with} \emph{a} \textless{} \emph{b}. and
the conclusion of the theorem is statement \emph{B}

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle B
\end{align*} = \emph{for all real numbers y between $f$(a) and $f$(b)
there exists a real number c in the interval {[}a, b {]} such that $f$(c)
= y}.

And so the Intermediate Value Theorem is simply the statement

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
A \Rightarrow B
\end{align*} And its negation is the statement

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
A \land \lnot B
\end{align*}

We'll need the negation of statement \emph{B} for this:

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle \lnot B
\end{align*} = \emph{there exists a real number y between
$f$(a) and $f$(b) such that for all real number c in the interval {[}a, b
{]} we have $f$(c) $\neq$ y}.

And so the negation is

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\emph{There exists a continuous function $f$ on the interval}
{[}\emph{a},\emph{b} {]}, \emph{with} \emph{a} \textless{} \emph{b} such
that there exists a real number y between $f$(a) and $f$(b) such that for
all real number c in the interval {[}a, b {]} we have $f$(c) $\neq$ y''.
\end{description}
sols_raw:
The Intermediate Value Theorem states:
:For any real numbers ''a'' < ''b'', and for any function
::<math>f: [a,b] \to \mathbb{R},</math>
:if ''f'' is continuous on the interval [''a'',''b'' ], then for every real number ''y'' between ''f''(''a'') and ''f''(''b''), there exists a real number ''c'' in the interval [''a'',''b'' ] such that ''f''(''c'')=''y''.

We can usually spot implications in theorems by the use of the word ''then''. So here we have that the statement ''A'' is
:<math>\displaystyle A</math> = ''&fnof; is a continuous function on the interval'' [''a'',''b'' ], ''with'' ''a'' < ''b''.
and the conclusion of the theorem is statement ''B''
:<math>\displaystyle B</math> = ''for all real numbers y between &fnof;(a) and &fnof;(b) there exists a real number c in the interval [a, b ] such that &fnof;(c) = y''.

And so the Intermediate Value Theorem is simply the statement
:<math>\displaystyle
A \Rightarrow B
</math>
And its negation is the statement
:<math>\displaystyle
A \land \lnot B
</math>

We'll need the negation of statement ''B'' for this:
:<math>\displaystyle \lnot B</math> = ''there exists a real number y between &fnof;(a) and &fnof;(b) such that for all real number c in the interval [a, b ] we have &fnof;(c) &ne; y''.

And so the negation is

:''There exists a continuous function &fnof; on the interval'' [''a'',''b'' ], ''with'' ''a'' < ''b'' such that there exists a real number y between &fnof;(a) and &fnof;(b) such that for all real number c in the interval [a, b ] we have &fnof;(c) &ne; y''.
statement_html:
The Intermediate Value Theorem states:

For any real numbers a < b, and for any function

\(f: [a,b]\to \mathbb{R},\)

if f is continuous on the interval [a,b ], then for every real number y between f(a) and f(b), there exists a real number c in the interval [a,b ] such that f(c)=y.

Write down the negation of this statement. (Don’t worry that the negation will be a false statement - just negate the statement correctly).

if \emph{f} is continuous on the interval {[}\emph{a},\emph{b} {]}, then
